However, in the end, even more than JFK, he was talked into involvement by his advisers. Guilty as charged. Nixon was not often talked into dumb foreign policy things (though foolishly was by Kissinger to get involved with the PR fracas with the invasion of Cambodia), nor was Eisenhower in concern to Vietnam.

It’s complicated and there are a lot of answers. None of them are right; all of them are differing degrees of wrong. Pick your poison. Maybe we got involved because the French got chased out. The French did get chased out of Vietnam, they were (and are) NATO allies, and their colonial proxies in the area had a reasonable claim on “hey, you guys said you had our backs.” Maybe we got involved because of Containment. George Kennan wrote his famous “X Telegram” which essentially said “the way you defeat communism is you prevent it from spreading.” Communism was threatening to engulf South East Asia and the United States policy was to resist. Maybe that’s why we got involved. Or maybe we got involved because of the Gulf of Tonkin incident. Sure, that basically didn’t happen the way it was sold to the American people but these things have a way of getting away from people. It’s very difficult to know who knew what when and what their intentions were at every step along the way, so even if Tonkin was a ruse, it’s not clear who got hoodwinked. Or maybe we got involved because Johnson was lost without Kennedy and was never really included in foreign policy conversations until Kennedy was shot. Maybe that’s why military advisors and some financial aid turned into a giant granite wall in Washington DC. Or maybe it was economics. American aid came with the caveat that it be spent on American goods shipped from American ports and that created a crushing pressure on the Vietnamese economy. The Americans bled the Vietnamese white while shutting out the rest of Asia and perhaps a number of them were unwilling to let that cash cow go. Maybe it's all of those things, maybe it’s none of them. Vietnam is a messy conflict that defies a lot of the traditional analytic tools for understanding it. In the end, the memorial in DC is poignant in more than one way: it’s somber and humbling, yes, but it sneaks up on you too.
